A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some questions have no answers; others may prove impossible for your family to answer. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc.): 29 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

   - Make a home for the family

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

    Through reading about it in every newspaper printed in States at that time.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought it was crazy.

12a. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? In summer we went by car.

12b. What means of transportation did you use? Come with a brother and his family.

13. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Struck at Saskatchewan Landing in snowstorm.

14. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? On the homestead for a time, lived in a tent until fall, when some storms came and broke the tent down, then moved out. Stayed for the winter at the homestead.

15. Where did you settle or take up land? District of North Battleford.

16. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Retired to Montana, 1940-1952.

17. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? They thought our move was crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? In December we went to Alberta with friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Come with a brother and his family.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.). Stopped at Saskatchewan Landing in snowstorm.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? On the homestead for a tent covered in a tarp until full when storms came and birds stole food from the ground out, stuck for the snow today were building on.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? District of North Battleford, west of Kyle.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. Retired to Montana, 1940 to 1952 due to ill health, came to Saskatoon to see new three children.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came? He farming.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   - About once a month.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   - Mr. James 16, 1879

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?
   - I was a locator and took people around and found homesteads for them.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West two brothers came one located in 1914.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   - A prairie fire in autumn 1907 lost her 60 town hall. Had hauled home 11 tons. Had to head north and 14 hours. This fire swept everything turned around came back to west they were unable to get back. Laid down rolled on railroad track.
